abstract: An article in the special Wealth and Personal Finance section on Sept. 10 about tax planning gave an incorrect attribution for a quotation about the dangers of inherited wealth. It was Scott D. Michel, a tax lawyer at Caplin & Drysdale — not Scott J. Bakal, a tax lawyer at Neal Gerber Eisenberg — who said: “You almost never see a criminal tax case where you have inherited wealth, because they come with inherited lawyers, inherited advisers, inherited accountants. There’s a structure in place. With people who start from nothing and end up under a waterfall of money, the structure isn’t there, and there’s nobody to say ‘no’ to an abusive shelter.
